awd_titl_txt: Dynamics and Stability of Nonlinear Waves
awd_abstract_narration:
Many physical processes are best described mathematically in terms of mathematical models that involve (partial differential) equations governing the interactions and dynamics of characteristic physical quantities, such as amplitude, voltage, or concentration to name a few.  Very often, one observes a group-like behavior, which is attributed to the existence and persistence of the so-called wave solutions of these mathematical models. The identification of such solutions and their stability (or instability) properties is of enormous importance in contemporary technological applications. On the other hand, precise information about instability and abnormal behavior (such as blow ups) provides valuable information about validity and applicability of mathematical models themselves. 

This research is aimed at providing new mathematical tools to study non-linear dispersive equations, which are mathematical models for water wave dynamics, magnetization of materials, propagation of light in optical devices and related phenomena of quantum mechanics, to name a few. In particular, the principal investigator (PI) aims obtaining precise, quantitative information about the long-time behavior of such systems. In addition, the PI will be actively engaged in the training of the new generation of scientists, who will need to have the technical expertise in several areas to meet the challenges in the analysis and computation of cutting-edge physical systems and their modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Partial Differential Equations have become an indispensable tool in the modeling of physical and biological systems, as well as engineering applications. Specifically and of significant interest in the community is the emergence and properties of coherent structures (such as solitary waves, traveling waves, and rogue waves, to mention a few), under appropriate regimes of parameters. Identifying these regimes as well as the functional and shape properties of such structures have become a mainstream task for the nonlinear science community in the last thirty years. The rigorous mathematical analysis of these models and around these special solutions, give important clues about the overall dynamics of the systems, as well as the expected long-time behavior, among other things.

The PI, in collaboration with Ph.D. students, and some junior collaborators and senior researchers, has concentrated his efforts in these studies. As a result, several major results were put forward. The mathematical tools developed to address these issue will help shape the area going forward, as well as provide a blueprint for future investigations into related problems. Specifically, the PI has considered a nonlinear Schroedinger equation with mixed nonlinearities,  provided existence criteria for the waves, along with sharp decay and stability properties.

In another notable series of works, the PI and collaborators have constructed waves in periodic media for various equations:  Ostrovsky, fractional NLS, Lugiato-Lefever as well as systems, such as Benney, Zakharov system and KdV-NLS.  Importantly, a complete stability description for these waves  has been provided.  

Another major line of research involves calculating precise asymptotics for quantities described in fluid mechanics, such as velocity, vorticity, buoyancy etc. The PI and collaborators have produced a series of results for the Boussinesq system, the surface quasi-geostrophics as well as the Landau-DeGennes model  in statistical physics. 

In terms of human resources and the goal of adequately preparing the workforce for the challenges of the fast-developing technological sector, the PI is happy to report, that during this period,  four Ph.D.  students  finished under his immediate  supervision.  One of these is a minority student. Two of the students have found post-doctoral positions (U of Alabama and UC - Riverside), while the other two have been placed in high-level industrial jobs (Sprint, Wells Fargo). The PI has attracted a cohort of new minority Ph.D. students.
